column1: Title: State COVID-19 Data and Policy Actions – Policy Actions | KFF

column7: Law Enforcement and Public Safety Personnel

column1: With continued limited supply of the COVID-19 vaccine, states are phasing in eligibility for the vaccine. Eligible populations vary across states.  Information on state COVID-19 vaccine priority populations is available [here](https://www.kff.org/other/state-indicator/state-covid-19-vaccine-priority-populations/).

Information in this table reflects eligibility as set by the state, except where decision-making is specifically delegated to the counties.  However, there may still be differences in eligibility across counties even in those states where decisions over who is eligible are made at the state level.
KFF analysis of state websites and COVID-19 vaccine plans.

*For state COVID-19 vaccine sources, please see:* [https://docs.google.com/document/d/1P_a4N4EslbOFjQ5dNY__BrqT4oKiQMvijdH-tqagEG8/edit](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1P_a4N4EslbOFjQ5dNY__BrqT4oKiQMvijdH-tqagEG8/edit)

*Congregate Settings*: places where groups of people reside in close contact with one another. Examples include group homes, homeless shelters, and behavioral health residential treatment centers. Definitions for congregate settings vary among states.
1. Starting June 1, Alaska will vaccinate tourists arriving at major airports in the state.
2. Students do not have to be residents.
3. Those who access healthcare in the state do not have to be residents.
5. Exception made for workers offered on-site vaccination by an employer.
7. Those whose primary care provider is in the state do not have to be residents.
8. Individuals can receive vaccine if permanent residence is not in Oregon but staying in Oregon (e.g., for school, staying with family)
9. Does not apply in Philadelphia, where one must be a resident of Philadelphia to be eligible
10. Must be a resident to access state-run mass vaccination clinics
